appendix.title: The Afghanistan Mission Network (AMN) Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards
appendix.para: Ref(A): NCI Agency Technical Report TR-2013/ACO008868/04 - Dated 01 July 2013

sect2.title: General
sect2.para: NATO, through its interoperability directive, has recognized that widespread interoperability is a key component in achieving effective and efficient operations. In many of the operations world-wide in which the military of the NATO nations are engaged, they participate together with a wide variety of the military of other nations and non-military organizations on the ground. The NATO Interoperability Standards and Profile (NISP) provides the necessary guidance and technical components to support project implementations and transition to NATO Network Enabled Capability (NNEC).

sect2.title: Authorised Version
sect2.para: The standards extant for the AMN are described in the NISP. This is published as ADatP-34 by the NATO C3 Board. As part of the NISP, an AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been published among the several operational profiles permitted as part of ADatP-34. The latest authorised version can be found in Volume 4 of the NISP [ADaTP-34(G)-REV1, Volume 4 Annex D, 8 March 2013]. These are the extant and NATO agreed list of practical standards to achieve immediately usable interoperability between the national network extensions of the NATO nations, coalition partners and NATO provided capabilities.
Nations participating in the AMN have agreed to comply with the AMN joining instructions, of which these standards form an integral part.

sect2.title: Application
sect2.para: The AMN Profile will be used in the implementation of NATO Common Funded Systems. Nations participating in AMN agree to use this profile at Network Interconnection Points (NIPs) and at other Service Interoperability Points as applicable.

NNEC Services must be able to function in a network environment containing firewalls and various routing and filtering schemes; therefore, developers must use standard and well-known ports wherever possible, and document non-standard ports as part of their service interface. Service developers must assume network behaviour and performance consistent with the existing limits of these networks, taking bandwidth limitations and potentially unreliable networks into account.

sect2.title: Life-Cycle of Standards
sect2.para: ADatP-34 defines four stages within the life-cycle of a standard: emerging, mandatory, fading and retired. In those situations where multiple stages are mentioned, the AMN Profile recommends dates by which the transition to the next stage is to be completed by all AMN members. If a TCN (or NCI Agency) decides to implement emerging standards it is her responsibility to maintain backwards compatibility to the mandatory standard.

sect2.title: Forthcoming/Agreed Changes
sect2.para: Volume 4 of the Joining, Membership and Exit Instructions (JMEI) is oriented around the AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards. The AMN Profile is maintained within this document.

The extant authorised version of the AMN Profile is as published in ADaTP-34(G). This formal published version of the AMN Profile is to only be originated from this document (i.e. Vol 4 of the JMEI published as NCI Agency Technical Report TR-2013/ACO008868/04).

The NCI Agency acts as the custodian for the AMN Profile and is to be used as the conduit for changes (via her membership of the AMN AWG). This must be via the process outlined at section 2.7 of the JMEI Volume 4

Any changes already collectively agreed by the AMN TCN and NCI Agency via the AMN AWG for use on the AMN but not yet published in ADaTP-34 were indicated as changes in the document. These changes will be submitted for publication in the next authorised issue of ADatP-34 (i.e. ADaTP-34(H) and thereafter).

sect2.title: Relationship to NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy
sect2.para: The AMN has been designed and is managed as far as possible using a service approach. The AMN Services are based on the NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy [AC/322-N(2012)0092-AS1].

The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to identify particular services and associated Service Interoperability Point where two entities will interface and the standards in use by the relevant systems.
Where required, the implementation of the standard is described in an annex associated with the Service.

Where a composite suite of services (with their standards) are required to implement a suite of services that are typically grouped together to form a familiar “composite service” or a “user facing Service”, then the implementation annex is housed at the assessed “centre of gravity” of the composite service. This is done simply to keep the instructions together. This applies for those services which network engineers, system administrators, users or operators recognise as distinct (e.g. “Text based Chat”, “VoSIP” or “VTC”), and for which technical skills/specialisms/instructions already exist. For Example the VTC implementation annex is placed under “Enterprise Support Services” despite the fact that the VTC is also affected by settings implemented in “Communications Access Services”.
The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to structure this document, commencing with Communications and working up the Taxonomy from beneath.

sect2.title: Relationship to the Future (Federated) Mission Network
sect2.para: Subsequent NATO led missions will benefit from the modular nature of the AMN Profile, which will allow for maximum reuse of established capabilities, while accommodating unique requirements and technology improvements.

Based on the AMN Profile, a Federated Mission Network Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been proposed and is anticipated to be published in the next version of ADaTP-34. This will support the implementation of the Future Mission Network (FMN) Concept [MCM-0125-2012].

Given the strong linkage between AMN and FMN, the opportunity to maintain a single Federated Mission Network Profile is possible in future versions of this document, but will firstly require the establishment of the FMN Governance and FMN Framework Management Structures. To this end it is anticipated that any future development of capabilities for the AMN in the future should be done in the direction indicated by the Federated Mission Network Profile.

This AMN Profile contains footnotes from the FMN Profile that if applied would implement the AMN in the direction of the FMN. These are indicated as a footnote to the referenced standard. Please note however: The FMN notes are only included for information. They are not yet approved by the AWG for use on the AMN.

sect2.title: Transmission and Transport Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transmission Services cover the physical layer (also referred to as media layer or air-interface in wireless/satellite (SATCOM) communications) supporting Transport Services, as well as Communications Access Services. Support for the latter is relevant to personal communications systems, in which the User Appliances directly connect to the transmission element without any transport elements in between.

Definition: Transport Services provide resource-facing services, providing metro and wide-area connectivity to the Communications Access Services that operate at the edges of the network. In that role, Transport Services interact with the Transmission Services using them as the physical layer fabric supporting the transfer of data over a variety of transmission bearers as and where needed.

sect1.title: Enterprise Support Services
sect1.para: Definition: Enterprise Support Services are a set of Community Of Interest (COI) independent services that must be available to all members within the AMN. Enterprise Support Services facilitate other service and data providers on the federated networks by providing and managing underlying capabilities to facilitate collaboration and information management for end-users.

For the purposes of this Volume, Enterprise Support Services will be broken up further into:
Unified Communication and Collaboration Services
Information Management Services
Geospatial Services

sect2.title: Unified Communication and Collaboration Services
sect2.para: Definition: Unified Communication and Collaboration Services provide users with a range of interoperable collaboration capabilities, based on standards that fulfill operational requirements. They will enable real-time situational updates to time-critical planning activities between coalition partners, communities of interest (e.g. the Intel community or the Logistics community), and other agencies. Levels of collaboration include awareness, shared information, coordination and joint product development.

Different use cases require different levels of protection of these communication and collaboration services. For voice or audio-based collaboration services, the AMN profile can provide interoperability standards for two different scenarios
FMN: Under the FMN profile, 3 scenarios are offered. The first being pure Voice over IP (VoIP) network services, i.e. conventional IP telephony. The choice of this over VoSIP being purely based on classification of the network.:
A. Voice over Secure IP (VoSIP) network services
B. Network agonistic Secure Voice Services (such as 3G, IP/4G, ISDN)

On AMN, VoSIP is mandatory. If however network agnostic Secure Voice services are required in addition to VoSIP
The only scenario where this would apply would be in the case that crypto devices cannot be supplied, protected and managed on site and physical access to the AMN is hence not available at that location., then SCIP specifications as defined for audio-based collaboration services (end-to-end protected voice) over any network should be used
If SCIP is used, then access to the AMN can only be possible if a gateway for SCIP multi-conferencing and interconnection to VoSIP networks is provided. AMN. Additionally to achieve this there would need to be agreement to re-use a Key Management system that is already deployed in ISAF (for example that used for the OMLTs).. [Note this has been included due to the emerging requirements regarding RSM]

For text-based collaboration there is also a basic profile sufficient for operating this service with reduced protection requirements as well as an enhanced XMPP profile that includes additional security mechanisms.

sect2.para: Definition: COI-Enabling Services provide COI-dependant functionality required by more than one communities of interest. Applications must support the following browsers: Microsoft Internet Explorer v9.0 and newer, and Mozilla Firefox 12.0 and newer. When a supported browser is not true to the standard, choose to support the browser.

Some organizations or end-user devices do not allow the use of proprietary extensions such as Adobe Flash or Microsoft Silverlight. Those technologies shall be avoided. Implementers should use open standard based solutions (HTML5 / CSS3) instead.
Some AMN members do not allow the use of ActiveX controls in the browser. Browser plug-ins will need to be approved by AMN Change Advisory Board (CAB).

sect1.title: Service Management and Control
sect1.para: Definition: Service Management and Control (SMC) provides a collection of capabilities to coherently manage components in a federated service-enabled information technology infrastructure. SMC tools enable service providers to provide the desired quality of service as specified by the customer. In a federated environment such as the AMN, utilizing common process and data is a critical enabler to management of the network.
